title: One For Arthur is one to follow, says trainer Lucinda Russell
text:
Trainer Lucinda Russell believes the low mileage on the clock of 2017 Grand National winner One For Arthur means he can still be a major force in big staying chases.

The 10-year-old will make his seasonal debut in the Belhaven Brewery Chase, a contest he won in 2016, at Kelso on Saturday.

It will be One For Arthur’s fourth run since the Grand National win.

Trainer Luicnda Russell believes One For Arthur can still impress in big staying chases

He missed the following season with a tendon injury and was then sixth to Tiger Roll in last season’s Grand National having had only two previous runs — neither of which he completed — in a season disrupted by unsuitable ground and the racing shutdown caused by equine flu.

Russell said: ‘He is better than he has ever been which is odd to say when he is 10. He has had two very quiet seasons so he is very fresh and even before that we never over-raced him.

‘After the Saturday the plan will be to go back to Aintree in December for the Becher Chase again.’

The 10-year-old will make his seasonal debut in the Belhaven Brewery Chase on Saturday

After British Champions Day at Ascot on Saturday, the jumps season moves up another gear with the two-day Cheltenham October meeting starting on Saturday.

But one equine star missing will be Willie Mullins-trained Wicklow Brave who suffered a fatal fall at the final fence, fracturing his right shoulder, when poised to win Saturday’s American Grand National under jockey Paul Townend.

The versatile 10-year-old was a winner of 17 of his 59 races and his demise handed the American Grand National £212,000 first prize to Nicky Henderson-trained Brain Power.
